docs.title: Civic Transparency (Draft)
docs.text:
Provenance & Behavior Transparency An exploratory, privacy-respecting framework for understanding how public content spreads online.

  • GitHub Repository
  • Hosted Draft Documentation

This site documents experimental schema drafts and research ideas under active development.

docs.title: Project Vision
docs.text:
Explore the feasibility of a behavioral transparency dashboard that:

  • Ingests public, ToS-compliant data from platforms with usable APIs.
  • Surfaces burst activity, coordination, and automation patterns without analyzing post content.
  • Publishes aggregated behavioral signals rather than identifying individuals.
  • Offers exploration tools for researchers, journalists, and civic technologists.

docs.title: Motivation
docs.text:
Online manipulation thrives in opacity. We do not judge message content or viewpoints. Instead, we visualize how content spreads.

For platforms, our goal is to use low-cost metadata and aggregation methods to minimize operational risk and simplify adoption.

docs.title: Exploratory Model
docs.text:
1. Provenance Tags A proposed schema of non-identifying metadata at post time:
  2. Account age bucket
  3. Reshare flag
  4. Media reuse flag

  5. Automation status (if detectable)

  6. Transparency Endpoint A low-cost, unauthenticated API that platforms could expose:

  7. Input: trend, hashtag, or topic

  8. Output: anonymized stats by signal type and time range

  9. Privacy by Design

  10. No identifiers or message content
  11. Only aggregated results
  12. Bucketed metrics (e.g., k ≥ 100)
  13. No user scoring or permanent identifiers

docs.title: Why Might Platforms Participate?
docs.text:
• Proactive trust-building. Offers visibility without revealing users.

  • Low overhead. Metadata is computed once; aggregation is lightweight.

  • Regulatory alignment. Potential fit with EU DSA and similar transparency mandates.

docs.title: Why It Might Help the Public
docs.text:
• Fact-checkers and journalists can analyze trend origin and scale.
  • Civic groups can detect astroturfing or amplification.
  • Voters and researchers gain clarity on coordination dynamics.

docs.title: Design Principles
docs.text:
• Behavioral, not ideological. No classification of content or users.

  • No centralized authority. All methods and signals are open for review and critique.

  • Aggregate-first. Computation happens internally; only grouped results are published.

docs.title: Areas of Exploration
docs.text:
• Account age skews
  • Reshared/recycled media bursts
  • Hashtag/topic-level automation rates
  • Coordinated posting patterns
  • Platform-agnostic schema and API prototypes

docs.title: Privacy and Safety
docs.text:
What this project does NOT do:

  • Reveal individual users, IP addresses, or message content
  • Classify sentiment, misinformation, or intent
  • Score users or create reputational data
  • Interfere with private communications

docs.title: Risks We Consider
docs.text:
• Evasion tactics: actors may adapt → Combine multiple signals, refine methods

  • Gaming behavior: flooding or noise → Multi-modal analysis (e.g., media hashes, URL reuse)

  • Public discomfort: perceived surveillance → Keep all outputs non-personal and non-identifying

docs.title: Exploratory Outcomes (Hypothetical)
docs.text:
• Short term: Coordination visualizations inform journalists
  • Mid term: Platforms experiment with test implementations
  • Long term: Shared civic infrastructure to spot manipulation early

docs.title: Civic Transparency — Integrated Specification
docs.text: This page compiles the entire specification into a single, print-friendly view for sharing or review. For navigable sections, use the sidebar; for a quick overview, read straight through.

docs.title: About Specs: Provenance Tag
docs.text:
Status: Human-readable overview. Normative definition: See the JSON Schema at spec/schemas/provenance_tag.schema.json ($id: https://civic-interconnect.github.io/civic-transparency-spec/en/spec/schemas/provenance_tag.schema.json)

Added to public posts (stored server-side for aggregate queries; not shown per-user unless a platform chooses to).

Fields (bucketed / coarse): - acct_age_bucket — e.g., 0-7d, 8-30d, 1-6m, 6-24m, 24m+ - acct_type — person, org, media, public_official, unverified (optional: declared_automation) - automation_flag — manual, scheduled, api_client, declared_bot (self-labeled) - post_kind — original, reshare, quote, reply - client_family — web, mobile, third_party_api (no specific app IDs) - media_provenance — c2pa_present, hash_only, none - origin_hint — coarse locale bucket (country/region), only where lawful - dedup_hash — rolling/normalized hash for identical/near-identical text/media

Privacy & neutrality - Bucketed categories only; no handles, PII, or message content. - Used to compute aggregate transparency metrics (not to score individuals).

Conformance & stability - Implementations MUST validate against the JSON Schema. - Changes follow semver; breaking changes bump the schema’s MAJOR. - Platforms SHOULD publish method notes describing how they populate each field.

Non-normative example

{
  "acct_age_bucket": "1-6m",
  "acct_type": "person",
  "automation_flag": "scheduled",
  "post_kind": "reshare",
  "client_family": "mobile",
  "media_provenance": "c2pa_present",
  "origin_hint": "EU",
  "dedup_hash": "rhh_6f4c…"
}

docs.title: About Specs: Transparency API
docs.text:
Status: Human-readable overview. Normative definition: See OpenAPI at spec/schemas/transparency_api.openapi.yaml (response bodies conform to JSON Schemas in spec/schemas/*.schema.json)

Public, rate-limited endpoint that returns aggregated, privacy-preserving behavior signals.

docs.title: Request (illustrative)
docs.text:
GET /transparency/v1/aggregate
  ?topic=#CityElection2026
  &window_start=2026-02-01T00:00Z
  &window_end=2026-02-07T00:00Z
  &granularity=hour

docs.title: Response (illustrative)
docs.text:
{
  "topic": "#CityElection2026",
  "time_window": ["2026-02-01T00:00:00Z", "2026-02-07T00:00:00Z"],
  "series": [
    {
      "ts": "2026-02-03T12:00:00Z",
      "volume": 18423,
      "originals": 543,
      "shares": 12977,
      "reshare_ratio": 0.93,
      "acct_age_mix": {"0-7d":0.22,"8-30d":0.11,"1-6m":0.19,"6-24m":0.17,"24m+":0.31},
      "automation_mix": {"manual":0.71,"scheduled":0.14,"api_client":0.11,"declared_bot":0.04},
      "client_mix": {"web":0.47,"mobile":0.41,"third_party_api":0.12},
      "recycled_content_rate": 0.28,
      "c2pa_rate": 0.06,
      "coordination_signals": {
        "burst_score": 0.87,
        "synchrony_index": 0.74,
        "duplication_clusters": 11
      }
    }
  ]
}

docs.title: Conformance & privacy
docs.text:
• Responses MUST meet k-anonymity thresholds (e.g., k ≥ 100); small cells are suppressed.
  • No per-account identifiers or message content in API outputs.
  • Implementers MUST validate response bodies against the published JSON Schemas.

docs.title: Stability & versioning
docs.text:
• API is versioned at the path (/v1/…).

  • Backwards-compatible changes (new fields) increment MINOR; breaking changes bump the API MAJOR and corresponding schema versions.

docs.title: Operational guidance (non-normative)
docs.text:
• Publish rate limits and caching headers; prefer cached windows for popular topics.
  • Log k-anonymity enforcement decisions for auditor review.

docs.title: Metrics
docs.text: These metrics are designed to be simple, robust, and privacy-preserving.

docs.title: 1. burst_score
docs.text: Definition: The extent to which the current volume of a topic exceeds its trailing baseline. Example Calculation: Z-score or exponentially weighted moving average (EWMA) anomaly detection. Purpose: Identify sudden spikes in activity.

docs.title: 2. synchrony_index
docs.text: Definition: The proportion of posts arriving in unusually tight time bins from distinct accounts within a short window. Purpose: Reveal highly synchronized or "marching" posting behavior.

docs.title: 3. recycled_content_rate
docs.text: Definition: The share of posts whose dedup_hash appears more than N times in M minutes. Purpose: Detect repeated use of identical or near-identical content.

docs.title: 4. mixes
docs.text: Definition: Distributions of acct_age_bucket, automation_flag, client_family, and post_kind. Purpose: Show the composition of activity using broad, non-identifying attributes.

docs.title: 5. coordination_clusters (optional)
docs.text: Definition: Count of connected components where accounts post near-simultaneously identical content. Purpose: Provide additional context for coordinated campaigns.

docs.title: Privacy & Publication Rules
docs.text:
• All metrics are computed in aggregate.
  • Minimum cell size: N ≥ 100 accounts per output bucket.
  • No identifiers or individual post content is stored or released.

docs.title: Privacy
docs.text: The Civic Transparency framework is designed with privacy by design at its core.

docs.title: Guiding Principles
docs.text:
1. No personal data. The system does not collect or expose account IDs, handles, user names, or message text.

  2. Bucketed fields. Potentially sensitive attributes (e.g., account age, follower count) are reported only in broad, non-identifying ranges.

  3. Aggregate-only outputs. All metrics are computed across large groups; no individual-level records are exposed.

  4. Minimum group size thresholds. Public outputs are only generated when k-anonymity ≥ 100 is satisfied, reducing re-identification risk.

  5. No cross-platform joins. Schema design avoids linkable identifiers across platforms, making external joining infeasible.

docs.title: Built-in Safeguards
docs.text:
• Small-count suppression. Metrics for small groups are suppressed to prevent triangulation attacks.

  • Raw-post decoupling. Public outputs are derived from aggregate computations, not individual post logs.

  • Internal-only provenance tags. Tags are used to compute trends and coordination patterns, but never exposed at the individual post level.

docs.title: Legal & Ethical Compliance
docs.text:
• Privacy-aligned. Meets the intent of privacy regulations such as the GDPR, CCPA, and other global standards.

  • Transparency-compliant. Enables platforms to meet obligations under emerging transparency laws (e.g., the EU Digital Services Act) without revealing personally identifiable information.

This privacy approach is central to building trust while enabling visibility into coordinated behavior online.

Observatory on Social Media (OSoMe), Indiana University Research group behind Botometer and Hoaxy; studies online manipulation and coordination. See https://osome.iu.edu/.

synchrony_index Proportion of posts landing in unusually tight inter-arrival bins from distinct accounts.

docs.title: Survey of Related Efforts and Research Groups
docs.text: This draft page lists relevant organizations and initiatives whose work overlaps with or informs the goals of Civic Transparency.

docs.title: Open Standards & Provenance Technology
docs.text:
• C2PA (Coalition for Content Provenance and Authenticity) A standardization effort led by Adobe, Microsoft, BBC, and others to embed media provenance into digital assets.

  • Starling Lab (Stanford + USC Shoah Foundation) Applies cryptographic methods to ensure the integrity of digital media and memory.

  • Adobe Content Credentials Creator-facing implementation of C2PA providing visible provenance and editing history.

docs.title: Coordination & Inauthentic Behavior Research
docs.text:
• Observatory on Social Media (Indiana University) Maintainers of tools like Botometer and Hoaxy for analyzing bot-like behavior and network diffusion.

  • Graphika Investigates online narrative ecosystems, often for governments or nonprofits.

  • DFRLab (Digital Forensic Research Lab, Atlantic Council) Conducts field and open-source investigations of information operations.

  • Global Disinformation Index (GDI) Provides domain-level risk scores for disinformation, platform-agnostic.

  • Meedan Develops open-source tools and training programs for media verification and fact-checking.

docs.title: Open-Source Civic-Tech Projects
docs.text:
• Pol.is A real-time, open-source deliberation platform for participatory governance.

  • SMAT (Social Media Analysis Toolkit) A civic-tech toolkit from UCLA for exploring social media discourse and coordination.

  • MIT Media Lab: Laboratory for Social Machines Now archived; previously explored networked public narratives and civic media.

This is a working draft. If you know of other relevant tools, datasets, or civic research efforts, please open an issue or submit a pull request.

docs.title: Common Weakness Enumeration (CWE) Catalog for Transparency
docs.text:
This is an initial CWE catalog for Civic Transparency implementations. It will grow as real-world platform audits surface recurring design and deployment issues.

Each CWE highlights a common risk in system behavior, privacy, or transparency reliability.

docs.title: CWE Catalog
docs.text:
• CWE-T001: Missing Provenance Tagging
  • CWE-T002: Overly Specific Client Identifiers in Public Data
  • CWE-T003: Weak Deduplication Hash or Normalization
  • CWE-T004: Inconsistent K-Anonymity Enforcement
  • CWE-T005: Aggregates Without Clear Time Windows
  • CWE-T006: Non-Rate-Limited Public Transparency API
  • CWE-T007: Missing or Unverifiable Media Provenance
  • CWE-T008: Public Exposure of Raw Duplication Clusters

docs.title: Notes
docs.text: CWEs are designed for platform implementers, auditors, and researchers. They do not apply to scenario/test data in this repository, where provenance and coordination signals may be fully labeled for teaching and validation purposes.

docs.title: Description
docs.text: Platform fails to attach required provenance tags (acct_age_bucket, automation_flag, etc.) to public posts, making downstream aggregate metrics incomplete.

docs.title: Potential Impact
docs.text:
• Reduced ability to detect coordinated or inauthentic activity.
  • Metrics based on partial tagging may mislead analysts.

docs.title: Detection
docs.text:
• Compare expected proportion of tagged posts with actual coverage.
  • Audit logs of tag assignment in ingestion pipeline.

docs.title: Mitigation
docs.text:
• Implement automated checks in the ingestion pipeline to ensure provenance tags are applied before data is stored or published.
  • Add unit and integration tests for all tag assignment functions.
  • Monitor real-time tagging coverage metrics and trigger alerts if they drop below thresholds.
  • Provide fallback tagging logic for posts missing metadata from upstream systems.

docs.title: CWE-T002: Overly Specific Client Identifiers in Public Data
Description
docs.text: Public outputs include fine-grained client/app identifiers rather than coarse client_family.

docs.title: Potential Impact
docs.text: • Fingerprinting risk; privacy leakage about user devices or apps.

docs.title: Detection
docs.text: • Scan published fields for app IDs, UA strings, SDK versions.

docs.title: Mitigation
docs.text: • Use coarse buckets: web, mobile, third_party_api. Strip specific client names.

docs.title: CWE-T003: Weak Deduplication Hash or Normalization
Description
docs.text: Deduplication hashes may use fragile normalization techniques (e.g., whitespace-only normalization) or rely on weak hash functions.

docs.title: Potential Impact
docs.text:
• Recycled or near-duplicate content may go undetected.
  • Unstable hashes may cause false positives due to minor formatting changes.

docs.title: Detection
docs.text:
• Test hash stability across small variations in text or media.
  • Check for collisions under common transformations (e.g., spacing, emoji variants, URL encodings).

docs.title: Mitigation
docs.text:
• Apply robust normalization:
  • Case folding
  • URL canonicalization

  • Emoji and Unicode normalization

  • Use strong, collision-resistant hashing techniques (e.g., cryptographic hashes or rolling hashes for long content).

docs.title: Description
docs.text: Different endpoints or time windows apply different k thresholds or leak small cells.

docs.title: Potential Impact
docs.text: • Re-identification risk; deanonymization via differencing.

docs.title: Detection
docs.text: • Attempt differencing across adjacent windows/breakdowns.

docs.title: Mitigation
docs.text: • Enforce a single global k (e.g., ≥100) with suppression or smoothing; log enforcement.

docs.title: CWE-T005: Aggregates Without Clear Time Windows
Description
docs.text: Published metrics lack explicit window start/end and granularity.

docs.title: Potential Impact
docs.text: • Misinterpretation of bursts/synchrony; apples-to-oranges comparisons.

docs.title: Detection
docs.text: • Check for time_window and interval in responses.

docs.title: Mitigation
docs.text: • Include window_start, window_end, and granularity in every response.

docs.title: Description
docs.text: Public endpoint allows high request rates without limits.

docs.title: Potential Impact
docs.text: • Abuse, cost spikes, denial-of-service.

docs.title: Detection
docs.text: • Probe rate limits and error codes.

docs.title: Mitigation
docs.text: • Add IP/user/app rate limits, caching, backoff hints; publish quotas.

docs.title: CWE-T007: Missing or Unverifiable Media Provenance
Description
docs.text: No C2PA or provenance indicator is surfaced in aggregates.

docs.title: Potential Impact
docs.text: • Harder to track recycled/edited media waves.

docs.title: Detection
docs.text: • Check that media_provenance is included in post-time tags and aggregated rates.

docs.title: Mitigation
docs.text: • Record c2pa_present | hash_only | none; publish c2pa_rate in aggregates.

docs.title: CWE-T008: Public Exposure of Raw Duplication Clusters
Description
docs.text: Raw dedup clusters or near-post sets are published.

docs.title: Potential Impact
docs.text: • Backdoor to re-identify accounts or content.

docs.title: Detection
docs.text: • Look for cluster member details in outputs.

docs.title: Mitigation
docs.text: • Publish count-only signals (e.g., duplication_clusters) and recycled rates; keep raw clusters internal.

  • SMAT (Social Media Analysis Toolkit) A civic-tech toolkit from UCLA for exploring social media discourse and coordination.

  • MIT Media Lab: Laboratory for Social Machines Now archived; previously explored networked public narratives and civic media.

This is a working draft. If you know of other relevant tools, datasets, or civic research efforts, please open an issue or submit a pull request.

docs.title: Common Weakness Enumeration (CWE) Catalog for Transparency
docs.text:
This is an initial CWE catalog for Civic Transparency implementations. It will grow as real-world platform audits surface recurring design and deployment issues.

Each CWE highlights a common risk in system behavior, privacy, or transparency reliability.

docs.title: CWE Catalog
docs.text:
• CWE-T001: Missing Provenance Tagging
  • CWE-T002: Overly Specific Client Identifiers in Public Data
  • CWE-T003: Weak Deduplication Hash or Normalization
  • CWE-T004: Inconsistent K-Anonymity Enforcement
  • CWE-T005: Aggregates Without Clear Time Windows
  • CWE-T006: Non-Rate-Limited Public Transparency API
  • CWE-T007: Missing or Unverifiable Media Provenance
  • CWE-T008: Public Exposure of Raw Duplication Clusters

docs.title: Notes
docs.text: CWEs are designed for platform implementers, auditors, and researchers. They do not apply to scenario/test data in this repository, where provenance and coordination signals may be fully labeled for teaching and validation purposes.

docs.title: Description
docs.text: Platform fails to attach required provenance tags (acct_age_bucket, automation_flag, etc.) to public posts, making downstream aggregate metrics incomplete.

docs.title: Potential Impact
docs.text:
• Reduced ability to detect coordinated or inauthentic activity.
  • Metrics based on partial tagging may mislead analysts.

docs.title: Detection
docs.text:
• Compare expected proportion of tagged posts with actual coverage.
  • Audit logs of tag assignment in ingestion pipeline.

docs.title: Mitigation
docs.text:
• Implement automated checks in the ingestion pipeline to ensure provenance tags are applied before data is stored or published.
  • Add unit and integration tests for all tag assignment functions.
  • Monitor real-time tagging coverage metrics and trigger alerts if they drop below thresholds.
  • Provide fallback tagging logic for posts missing metadata from upstream systems.

docs.title: CWE-T002: Overly Specific Client Identifiers in Public Data
Description
docs.text: Public outputs include fine-grained client/app identifiers rather than coarse client_family.

docs.title: Potential Impact
docs.text: • Fingerprinting risk; privacy leakage about user devices or apps.

docs.title: Detection
docs.text: • Scan published fields for app IDs, UA strings, SDK versions.

docs.title: Mitigation
docs.text: • Use coarse buckets: web, mobile, third_party_api. Strip specific client names.

docs.title: CWE-T003: Weak Deduplication Hash or Normalization
Description
docs.text: Deduplication hashes may use fragile normalization techniques (e.g., whitespace-only normalization) or rely on weak hash functions.

docs.title: Potential Impact
docs.text:
• Recycled or near-duplicate content may go undetected.
  • Unstable hashes may cause false positives due to minor formatting changes.

docs.title: Detection
docs.text:
• Test hash stability across small variations in text or media.
  • Check for collisions under common transformations (e.g., spacing, emoji variants, URL encodings).

docs.title: Mitigation
docs.text:
• Apply robust normalization:
  • Case folding
  • URL canonicalization

  • Emoji and Unicode normalization

  • Use strong, collision-resistant hashing techniques (e.g., cryptographic hashes or rolling hashes for long content).

docs.title: Description
docs.text: Different endpoints or time windows apply different k thresholds or leak small cells.

docs.title: Potential Impact
docs.text: • Re-identification risk; deanonymization via differencing.

docs.title: Detection
docs.text: • Attempt differencing across adjacent windows/breakdowns.

docs.title: Mitigation
docs.text: • Enforce a single global k (e.g., ≥100) with suppression or smoothing; log enforcement.

docs.title: CWE-T005: Aggregates Without Clear Time Windows
Description
docs.text: Published metrics lack explicit window start/end and granularity.

docs.title: Potential Impact
docs.text: • Misinterpretation of bursts/synchrony; apples-to-oranges comparisons.

docs.title: Detection
docs.text: • Check for time_window and interval in responses.

docs.title: Mitigation
docs.text: • Include window_start, window_end, and granularity in every response.

docs.title: Description
docs.text: Public endpoint allows high request rates without limits.

docs.title: Potential Impact
docs.text: • Abuse, cost spikes, denial-of-service.

docs.title: Detection
docs.text: • Probe rate limits and error codes.

docs.title: Mitigation
docs.text: • Add IP/user/app rate limits, caching, backoff hints; publish quotas.

docs.title: CWE-T007: Missing or Unverifiable Media Provenance
Description
docs.text: No C2PA or provenance indicator is surfaced in aggregates.

docs.title: Potential Impact
docs.text: • Harder to track recycled/edited media waves.

docs.title: Detection
docs.text: • Check that media_provenance is included in post-time tags and aggregated rates.

docs.title: Mitigation
docs.text: • Record c2pa_present | hash_only | none; publish c2pa_rate in aggregates.

docs.title: CWE-T008: Public Exposure of Raw Duplication Clusters
Description
docs.text: Raw dedup clusters or near-post sets are published.

docs.title: Potential Impact
docs.text: • Backdoor to re-identify accounts or content.

docs.title: Detection
docs.text: • Look for cluster member details in outputs.

docs.title: Mitigation
docs.text: • Publish count-only signals (e.g., duplication_clusters) and recycled rates; keep raw clusters internal.

docs.title: About Specs: Provenance Tag
docs.text:
Status: Human-readable overview. Normative definition: See the JSON Schema at spec/schemas/provenance_tag.schema.json ($id: https://civic-interconnect.github.io/civic-transparency-spec/en/spec/schemas/provenance_tag.schema.json)

Added to public posts (stored server-side for aggregate queries; not shown per-user unless a platform chooses to).

Fields (bucketed / coarse): - acct_age_bucket — e.g., 0-7d, 8-30d, 1-6m, 6-24m, 24m+ - acct_type — person, org, media, public_official, unverified (optional: declared_automation) - automation_flag — manual, scheduled, api_client, declared_bot (self-labeled) - post_kind — original, reshare, quote, reply - client_family — web, mobile, third_party_api (no specific app IDs) - media_provenance — c2pa_present, hash_only, none - origin_hint — coarse locale bucket (country/region), only where lawful - dedup_hash — rolling/normalized hash for identical/near-identical text/media

Privacy & neutrality - Bucketed categories only; no handles, PII, or message content. - Used to compute aggregate transparency metrics (not to score individuals).

Conformance & stability - Implementations MUST validate against the JSON Schema. - Changes follow semver; breaking changes bump the schema’s MAJOR. - Platforms SHOULD publish method notes describing how they populate each field.

Non-normative example

{
  "acct_age_bucket": "1-6m",
  "acct_type": "person",
  "automation_flag": "scheduled",
  "post_kind": "reshare",
  "client_family": "mobile",
  "media_provenance": "c2pa_present",
  "origin_hint": "EU",
  "dedup_hash": "rhh_6f4c…"
}

docs.title: Schema Index (Draft / Normative Artifacts)
docs.text:
This page lists draft machine-readable schemas for the Civic Transparency specification.

Human-readable explanations live in: - Provenance Tag (informative) - Transparency API (informative)

docs.title: Design Goals
docs.text: These schemas prioritize: - Behavior-only scope – no message content or identifiers. - Privacy preservation – bucketed values and k-anonymity safeguards. - Forward compatibility – extensible formats with stable IDs.

docs.title: JSON Schema (Draft-07)
docs.text:
Each schema is self-contained and versioned.

  • SeriesDoc $id: https://civic-interconnect.github.io/civic-transparency-spec/en/spec/schemas/series.schema.json File: spec/schemas/series.schema.json

  • MetaDoc $id: https://civic-interconnect.github.io/civic-transparency-spec/en/spec/schemas/meta.schema.json File: spec/schemas/meta.schema.json

  • RunDoc $id: https://civic-interconnect.github.io/civic-transparency-spec/en/spec/schemas/run.schema.json File: spec/schemas/run.schema.json

  • ProvenanceTag $id: https://civic-interconnect.github.io/civic-transparency-spec/en/spec/schemas/provenance_tag.schema.json File: spec/schemas/provenance_tag.schema.json

docs.title: OpenAPI
docs.text: • Transparency API File: spec/schemas/transparency_api.openapi.yaml All responses must validate against the JSON Schemas above.

docs.title: Versioning & Conformance
docs.text:
• Schemas follow semantic versioning:
  • MAJOR = breaking
  • MINOR = additive
  • PATCH = clarifying
  • Clients must pin to a specific version and validate before ingesting.
  • Changes and deprecations are documented in CHANGELOG.md.

docs.title: Code Generation (informative)
docs.text:
You can generate typed clients from the JSON Schemas.

# Example (Python + Pydantic)
datamodel-code-generator \
  --input spec/schemas/series.schema.json \
  --input-file-type jsonschema \
  --output src/ci/transparency/types/series.py

docs.title: Provenance & Privacy Notes
docs.text:
• Signals only: All values are behavioral, not textual.
  • Minimum group size: Enforced at the API layer (e.g., k ≥ 100).
  • PII-free by design: See Privacy for details.

docs.title: About Specs: Transparency API
docs.text:
Status: Human-readable overview. Normative definition: See OpenAPI at spec/schemas/transparency_api.openapi.yaml (response bodies conform to JSON Schemas in spec/schemas/*.schema.json)

Public, rate-limited endpoint that returns aggregated, privacy-preserving behavior signals.

docs.title: Request (illustrative)
docs.text:
GET /transparency/v1/aggregate
  ?topic=#CityElection2026
  &window_start=2026-02-01T00:00Z
  &window_end=2026-02-07T00:00Z
  &granularity=hour

docs.title: Response (illustrative)
docs.text:
{
  "topic": "#CityElection2026",
  "time_window": ["2026-02-01T00:00:00Z", "2026-02-07T00:00:00Z"],
  "series": [
    {
      "ts": "2026-02-03T12:00:00Z",
      "volume": 18423,
      "originals": 543,
      "shares": 12977,
      "reshare_ratio": 0.93,
      "acct_age_mix": {"0-7d":0.22,"8-30d":0.11,"1-6m":0.19,"6-24m":0.17,"24m+":0.31},
      "automation_mix": {"manual":0.71,"scheduled":0.14,"api_client":0.11,"declared_bot":0.04},
      "client_mix": {"web":0.47,"mobile":0.41,"third_party_api":0.12},
      "recycled_content_rate": 0.28,
      "c2pa_rate": 0.06,
      "coordination_signals": {
        "burst_score": 0.87,
        "synchrony_index": 0.74,
        "duplication_clusters": 11
      }
    }
  ]
}

docs.title: Conformance & privacy
docs.text:
• Responses MUST meet k-anonymity thresholds (e.g., k ≥ 100); small cells are suppressed.
  • No per-account identifiers or message content in API outputs.
  • Implementers MUST validate response bodies against the published JSON Schemas.

docs.title: Stability & versioning
docs.text:
• API is versioned at the path (/v1/…).

  • Backwards-compatible changes (new fields) increment MINOR; breaking changes bump the API MAJOR and corresponding schema versions.

docs.title: Operational guidance (non-normative)
docs.text:
• Publish rate limits and caching headers; prefer cached windows for popular topics.
  • Log k-anonymity enforcement decisions for auditor review.
